Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Wnt receptor activation, signal initiation and signal termination in vivo
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Proposal IOS-1353799
Marcel Wehrli, Ph.D.

Dynamics of Wnt receptor activation, signal initiation and signal termination in vivo

Cells of developing embryos and adult tissues must receive and precisely interpret specific signals for proper growth. Secreted proteins of the Wnt family represent one such signal. Wnts elicit precise changes in gene expression mediated by increased levels of the protein ?beta-catenin. Too much or too little signal leads to tissue defects and disease.

While it is known that Wnts activate cell surface receptors, it remains unclear where on the cell membrane or inside the cell the ligand-activated receptor functions, how it activates the intracellular signaling cascade via the protein Dishevelled and how the receptor is turned off. This proposal addresses these questions directly with a novel in vivo approach. In addition, it will identify how Dishevelled blocks the central regulator in the pathway, a protein complex assembled around the scaffold protein Axin, and is expected to identify in vivo how the receptor-initiated signal leads to the inhibition of the Axin complex and induces beta-catenin signaling, a process that remains controversial.

Broader Impact
Our understanding of the Wnt/beta-catenin pathway has increased dramatically in recent years. However, many findings are derived from in vitro experiments and their functional significance is limited. The signaling events of the Wnt/beta-catenin pathway are amenable to investigation in their normal cellular context using the Drosophila model system, underscoring the significance of the studies proposed here. These investigations are expected to identify dynamically changing interactions as the signal is transduced, thereby greatly increasing our understanding of this important signaling mechanism.

This proposal will provide an opportunity for one graduate student and three undergraduates to engage in cutting edge research. In addition, it will allow the PI to introduce K-12 students to basic development and genetics and to promote a science-based curriculum in local schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cells of developing embryos and adult tissues must receive and precisely interpret specific signals for proper function. Secreted proteins of the Wnt family represent one such signal. Wnts elicit precise changes in gene expression mediated by increased levels of the protein beta-catenin. Too much or too little signal leads to tissue defects and disease. Importantly, the Wnt/beta-catenin pathway is conserved between mammals and the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster but displays less redundancy in Drosophila. This makes Drosophila an ideal model system to investigate the function of the Wnt/beta-catenin pathway and obtain insights expected to apply also to the mammalian system.

The key obstacle to investigations of the Wnt/beta-catenin signaling mechanism is that Wnt pathway activity is obscured: Most pathway components have additional functions for mechanisms other than Wnt signaling, for which they are more abundant. This precludes the use of immunohistochemistry, a standard method in cell biology. As an alternative, biochemistry has been used to reveal pathway activity from molecular interactions between components. However, as biochemical assays destroy tissues and cells, this information is lost. Thus we lack insight about how the pathway functions at a cellular level, causing controversies to persist.

We have overcome this obstacle by adapting Bimolecular Fluorescence Complementation (BiFC) methodology. This technique relies on the ability of two fragments of a fluorescent protein to complement each other and become fluorescent. This may occur if they are brought together in precisely the right way by fusion to components that interact with each other. In this way, BiFC reports the molecular interaction of these two components when and where it occurs in cells or tissue. Previously, BiFC had been shown to function using overexpression in animals or cells and was limited in scope. Here, we wished to express components at near-physiological levels in transgenic Drosophila and use BiFC to reveal the function of an entire mechanism. We needed to gauge feasibility and specificity of this method. We find that we detect robust BiFC in transgenic Drosophila that display constitutively and near-physiological expression of tagged components.

Eight components of the Wnt pathway were chosen for analysis by BiFC. We detected 17 pair-wise interactions. Several lines of evidence indicate BiFC is highly specific: (a) BiFC tags must be in precisely the right position for fluorescence to occur and tags in different positions serve as negative controls, (b) most pairs did not yield BiFC, (c) ubiquitous BiFC was rarely observed, arguing against non-specific interactions, (d) most BiFC pairs displayed graded distributions, indicative of regulation by Wnt pathway activity.

The central regulator of the Wnt pathway, termed the destruction complex (DC), had only been demonstrated biochemically, without detection of differences between active and inactivated DCs. We identified two BiFC pairs reporting DCs. Strikingly, these two BiFC pairs detect different conformations between active and inactivated DCs. Thus far, our reagents appear unique in detecting this critical difference.

Destruction complexes contain the scaffold protein Axin, the tumor suppressor APC and the kinase GSK3beta (Sgg in Drosophila). In the absence of Wnt, we find that active DCs are dispersed throughout the cytoplasm, explaining how they are effective in targeting beta-catenin for destruction. When ligand activates the receptor, this induces a translocation of DC to the receptor, which induces a conformational change that alters the interaction of the kinase GSK3beta/Sgg with Axin. This finding provides a novel mechanistic explanation for DC inactivation. Inactivated DC dissociate from the receptor and aggregate into a large super-complex. In the process, the cytoplasm is cleared of active destruction complex, allowing for beta-catenin accumulation and signaling.

Intellectual Merit: This project has demonstrated that BiFC faithfully reports molecular interactions at near-physiological levels of expression in transgenic animals. Importantly, BiFC reveals when and where interactions occur in cells and tissue. Here, BiFC was used to detect pair-wise interactions between the key components of the Wnt pathway. It demonstrates that BiFC technology can be applied to probe and analyze an entire mechanism or biological process. Once a 'library' of tagged components has been generated, they can be tested in all possible combinations to detect unexpected interactions. Notably, although molecular interactions are revealed both by BiFC and biochemistry, only BiFC also identifies the subcellular locations of such interactions. 

The investigation of the Wnt/beta-catenin signaling mechanism in this project has provided a new molecular model, revealing dynamic interactions during the transduction of the Wnt signal.

Broader Impact: The funding for this project provided the opportunity for one High School and ten undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds to gain advanced training in modern scientific methods. Notably, two undergraduate students are joint first authors on a major publication from this project. In addition, outreach included interactions with local elementary and High Schools, which introduced students to basic development and genetics (using Drosophila and the moth Manduca) and to promote a strong science curriculum in local schools.
